brief_description: Verbal aggression towards staff during personal care
body_text: During morning personal care in Quiet Lounge, service user became verbally aggressive, shouting and swearing at care staff. Staff member stepped back, gave space, and spoke calmly. Service user continued to refuse care. Staff left room for 10 minutes then returned with different colleague. Service user had calmed and accepted care from new staff member. Possible triggers: overtired, preferred male carer not available. ABC chart completed. Behaviour support plan reviewed - no changes needed. Service user later apologised to staff.

brief_description: Service user found on floor in Conservatory
body_text: Staff member entered Conservatory at 05:02 and found service user sitting on the floor. Service user stated they had been reaching for their walking frame and lost balance. No visible injuries noted. Vital signs checked and within normal limits. Neurological observations commenced as per falls protocol. Service user assisted to chair with hoist. Comfortable and alert. Family notified. Incident form completed. GP informed - no further action required at this time.

Service user refused all morning medications in Wet Room stating 'I don't need them'. Staff attempted gentle persuasion explaining importance of medication but service user became agitated. Decision made not to force medication to maintain relationship. Senior staff informed. Further attempt made 1 hour later by different staff member - medications accepted without issue. Mental capacity regarding medication decisions to be reviewed. GP aware.

Broken window pane discovered in Corridor during morning checks. Small crack in outer pane, no glass fragments in room. Cause unknown - possibly weather related. Area made safe, room secured and not in use pending repair. Maintenance informed. Emergency glazier contacted - repair scheduled for today. No injuries, no service users in room at time of discovery. All windows to be inspected as precaution. Manager notified.

Broken window pane discovered in Quiet Lounge during morning checks. Small crack in outer pane, no glass fragments in room. Cause unknown - possibly weather related. Area made safe, room secured and not in use pending repair. Maintenance informed. Emergency glazier contacted - repair scheduled for today. No injuries, no service users in room at time of discovery. All windows to be inspected as precaution. Manager notified.

Service user experienced tonic-clonic seizure in Bedroom lasting approximately 2 minutes. Staff protected head with cushion, cleared area, timed seizure, placed in recovery position once jerking stopped. Post-ictal period - confused and drowsy for approximately 20 minutes. Vital signs monitored and stable. Known epilepsy, last seizure 6 months ago. No injuries sustained during seizure. Recovery uneventful. GP contacted - medication review arranged. Detailed seizure record completed. Neurological observations continued for 4 hours post-seizure.

During medication round in Entrance Hall, staff member realised they had administered morning medications to incorrect service user. Error identified immediately. Both service users' medications checked - no harmful medications swapped. Senior staff informed immediately, both service users monitored closely for next 4 hours. No adverse effects noted. GP contacted and advised continued monitoring. Families informed and apologised to. Staff member retrained on checking procedures. Incident reviewed at clinical governance meeting.

Routine monthly weighing in Conservatory showed service user has lost 4kg in past month (current weight 52kg). Senior staff informed. Food charts reviewed - intake appears adequate but fluctuating. District nurse informed - will review at next visit. Skin tear risk assessment updated. Long sleeves recommended to protect fragile skin.

Family updated throughout. Falls risk assessment reviewed.

brief_description: Physical aggression - grabbed staff member's arm
body_text: While providing assistance in Entrance Hall, service user suddenly grabbed staff member's left forearm tightly. Staff member remained calm, asked service user to let go, which they did after approximately 5 seconds. Small red mark visible on staff arm but no broken skin. Cold compress applied, mark faded within 30 minutes. Service user appeared confused and did not recognise what had happened. Possible pain trigger - appeared to grimace when moved. PRN analgesia offered and accepted. Behaviour settled. No injury to staff member. Staff member completed incident form and body map.

Service user began choking while eating lunch in Entrance Hall. Staff member immediately intervened, encouraged coughing. Obstruction cleared after 3-4 strong coughs. Service user recovered quickly, breathing normally. Remained seated and observed for 15 minutes. No respiratory distress noted. Meal discontinued as precaution. SALT referral made urgently. Swallowing assessment to be completed before resuming normal diet. Soft diet and supervision implemented meanwhile. GP informed. Family contacted.

brief_description: Verbal aggression towards staff during personal care
body_text: During morning personal care in Kitchen, service user became verbally aggressive, shouting and swearing at care staff. Staff member stepped back, gave space, and spoke calmly. Service user continued to refuse care. Staff left room for 10 minutes then returned with different colleague. Service user had calmed and accepted care from new staff member. Possible triggers: overtired, preferred male carer not available. ABC chart completed. Behaviour support plan reviewed - no changes needed. Service user later apologised to staff.

During personal care in Quiet Lounge, staff member noticed several bruises to upper arms (approximately 2-3cm each, yellow/green in colour). Service user unable to explain how bruises occurred. Body map completed and photographed. Senior staff informed immediately. Safeguarding alert raised as per policy. Recent visitors and activities reviewed. No concerns identified but monitoring continues. Family contacted - unaware of any incidents. Safeguarding team to investigate. Service user observed for any further marks or changes in behaviour.

Tablet (later identified as Amlodipine 5mg) found on floor in Main Lounge during cleaning. Unable to determine which service user this belonged to. All service users in area checked - all MAR charts showed medications signed as given. Tablet disposed of as per policy. All staff reminded to observe service users swallowing medications. Medication administration procedures reviewed with team.

Service user experienced tonic-clonic seizure in Main Lounge lasting approximately 2 minutes. Staff protected head with cushion, cleared area, timed seizure, placed in recovery position once jerking stopped. Post-ictal period - confused and drowsy for approximately 20 minutes. Vital signs monitored and stable. Known epilepsy, last seizure 6 months ago. No injuries sustained during seizure. Recovery uneventful. GP contacted - medication review arranged. Detailed seizure record completed. Neurological observations continued for 4 hours post-seizure.

Routine monthly weighing in Corridor showed service user has lost 4kg in past month (current weight 52kg). Senior staff informed. Food charts reviewed - intake appears adequate but fluctuating. GP referral made urgently. Dietitian input requested. Possible causes being investigated - dental problems, infection, medication side effects, low mood. Daily food and fluid monitoring implemented. Fortified diet commenced. Family informed and concerned - will visit to encourage eating. MUST score calculated - medium risk.

During assisted transfer from wheelchair to armchair in Day Room, service user's legs gave way. Staff member supported controlled descent to floor, preventing injury. Service user assessed on floor - no pain or obvious injury. Assistance requested, two staff used hoist to transfer to bed for full assessment. Appeared shaken but no injuries sustained. Observations normal. Encouraged to rest. Physiotherapy referral made for mobility review.

Service user noted missing from Bathroom during routine check. Search of building commenced immediately. Not found on premises. CCTV checked - showed service user leaving via main entrance 15 minutes earlier. Police contacted immediately and description provided. Family informed. Staff member searched local area in vehicle. Police located service user 2 streets away, unharmed but confused. Returned to service safely. Full assessment completed - no injuries, appeared well. Mental capacity assessment to be completed. Door security system reviewed. Safeguarding alert raised. Best interest meeting arranged.

Service user refused all morning medications in Conservatory stating 'I don't need them'. Staff attempted gentle persuasion explaining importance of medication but service user became agitated. Decision made not to force medication to maintain relationship. Senior staff informed. Further attempt made 1 hour later by different staff member - medications accepted without issue. Mental capacity regarding medication decisions to be reviewed. GP aware.

Service user became resistive during personal care in Quiet Lounge, pushing staff away and shouting. Care abandoned immediately. Service user left to calm with regular checks from doorway. After 20 minutes, approached by familiar staff member with cup of tea. Service user accepted drink and appeared calmer. Personal care reattempted with different approach - service user cooperative. Trigger appeared to be rushing and feeling pressured. ABC chart completed. Reminder to all staff to allow extra time and not to rush. Service user's preferred routine discussed at handover.

Redness noted to sacral area during personal care in Day Room. Area measures approximately 2cm x 2cm, non-blanching. Service user denies pain or discomfort. Repositioning schedule reviewed and increased to 2-hourly. Barrier cream applied. Pressure-relieving cushion in use. Nutrition reviewed - adequate intake. District nurse to assess within 24 hours. Photography and body mapping completed. Waterlow score recalculated - remains high risk. Tissue viability nurse referral made.

Service user discovered on floor in Quiet Lounge by care staff during routine checks. Fall was unwitnessed. Service user unable to recall what happened but complained of pain to right hip. Left in position, emergency services called. Paramedics attended and conveyed to A&E for assessment. X-ray confirmed no fracture. Returned to service later same day. Post-falls protocol initiated. Family updated throughout. Falls risk assessment reviewed.

During medication round in Day Room, staff member realised they had administered morning medications to incorrect service user. Error identified immediately. GP contacted and advised continued monitoring. Families informed and apologised to. Staff member retrained on checking procedures. Incident reviewed at clinical governance meeting.

Tablet (later identified as Amlodipine 5mg) found on floor in Main Lounge during cleaning. Unable to determine which service user this belonged to. All service users in area checked - all MAR charts showed medications signed as given. Tablet disposed of as per policy. All staff reminded to observe service users swallowing medications. Medication administration procedures reviewed with team.

During personal care in Conservatory, staff member noticed several bruises to upper arms (approximately 2-3cm each, yellow/green in colour). Service user unable to explain how bruises occurred. Body map completed and photographed. Senior staff informed immediately. Safeguarding alert raised as per policy. Recent visitors and activities reviewed. No concerns identified but monitoring continues. Family contacted - unaware of any incidents. Safeguarding team to investigate. Service user observed for any further marks or changes in behaviour.

Service user reported to staff in Quiet Lounge that another service user 'took money from their room'. Senior staff informed immediately. Both service users spoken to separately. Room checked with service user - all belongings accounted for, no money missing. Service user appeared confused about allegation and later could not recall making it. Possible confabulation due to dementia. Documented as potential safeguarding concern. Manager informed, monitoring in place. Family updated. Valuables list checked - all items present.

Service user refused all morning medications in Outside Patio stating 'I don't need them'. Staff attempted gentle persuasion explaining importance of medication but service user became agitated. Decision made not to force medication to maintain relationship. Senior staff informed. Further attempt made 1 hour later by different staff member - medications accepted without issue. Mental capacity regarding medication decisions to be reviewed. GP aware.

brief_description: Physical aggression - grabbed staff member's arm
body_text: While providing assistance in Garden, service user suddenly grabbed staff member's left forearm tightly. Staff member remained calm, asked service user to let go, which they did after approximately 5 seconds. Small red mark visible on staff arm but no broken skin. Cold compress applied, mark faded within 30 minutes. Service user appeared confused and did not recognise what had happened. Possible pain trigger - appeared to grimace when moved. PRN analgesia offered and accepted. Behaviour settled. No injury to staff member. Staff member completed incident form and body map.

brief_description: Exit-seeking behaviour - attempted to leave building
body_text: Service user found at front entrance in Outside Patio attempting to open the door stating they needed to 'get home to cook dinner'. Gently redirected by staff using distraction technique. Offered cup of tea and biscuit which was accepted. Walked with staff to lounge where familiar music was playing. Became settled and engaged in conversation about past. Appeared to forget about leaving. Family member telephoned to provide reassurance which helped. No distress caused. Security settings on door checked and functioning correctly.

Staff protected head with cushion, cleared area, timed seizure, placed in recovery position once jerking stopped. Post-ictal period - confused and drowsy for approximately 20 minutes. Vital signs monitored and stable. Known epilepsy, last seizure 6 months ago. No injuries sustained during seizure. Recovery uneventful. GP contacted - medication review arranged. Detailed seizure record completed. Neurological observations continued for 4 hours post-seizure.

Redness noted to sacral area during personal care in Day Room. Area measures approximately 2cm x 2cm, non-blanching. Service user denies pain or discomfort. Photography and body mapping completed. Waterlow score recalculated - remains high risk. Tissue viability nurse referral made.

During personal care in Dining Room, care staff noticed 3cm skin tear to right forearm. Service user stated they must have caught it on wheelchair but couldn't remember when. Wound cleaned with saline, sterile dressing applied as per tissue viability protocol. Wound photographed and body map completed. Not infected, edges well approximated. District nurse informed - will review at next visit. Skin tear risk assessment updated. Long sleeves recommended to protect fragile skin.

Mental capacity regarding medication decisions to be reviewed. GP aware.

brief_description: Physical aggression - grabbed staff member's arm
body_text: While providing assistance in Activity Room, service user suddenly grabbed staff member's left forearm tightly. Staff member remained calm, asked service user to let go, which they did after approximately 5 seconds. Small red mark visible on staff arm but no broken skin. Cold compress applied, mark faded within 30 minutes. Service user appeared confused and did not recognise what had happened. Possible pain trigger - appeared to grimace when moved. PRN analgesia offered and accepted. Behaviour settled. No injury to staff member. Staff member completed incident form and body map.

GP contacted and advised continued monitoring. Families informed and apologised to. Staff member retrained on checking procedures. Incident reviewed at clinical governance meeting.

Trigger appeared to be rushing and feeling pressured. ABC chart completed. Reminder to all staff to allow extra time and not to rush. Service user's preferred routine discussed at handover.

Water leak discovered in ceiling of Wet Room during routine checks. Area immediately cordoned off, service users moved to alternative location. Maintenance contacted - attended within 30 minutes. Manager informed, contractors arranged for tomorrow. No service users or staff affected. All equipment removed from room.

brief_description: Service user found on floor in Dining Room
body_text: Staff member entered Dining Room at 05:38 and found service user sitting on the floor. Service user stated they had been reaching for their walking frame and lost balance. No visible injuries noted. Vital signs checked and within normal limits. Neurological observations commenced as per falls protocol. Service user assisted to chair with hoist. Comfortable and alert. Family notified. Incident form completed. GP informed - no further action required at this time.

Redness noted to sacral area during personal care in Outside Patio. Area measures approximately 2cm x 2cm, non-blanching. Service user denies pain or discomfort. Repositioning schedule reviewed and increased to 2-hourly. Barrier cream applied. Pressure-relieving cushion in use. Nutrition reviewed - adequate intake. District nurse to assess within 24 hours. Photography and body mapping completed. Waterlow score recalculated - remains high risk. Tissue viability nurse referral made.

Service user discovered on floor in Dining Room by care staff during routine checks. Fall was unwitnessed. Service user unable to recall what happened but complained of pain to right hip. Left in position, emergency services called. Paramedics attended and conveyed to A&E for assessment. X-ray confirmed no fracture. Returned to service later same day. Post-falls protocol initiated. Family updated throughout. Falls risk assessment reviewed.

Routine monthly weighing in Outside Patio showed service user has lost 4kg in past month (current weight 52kg). Senior staff informed. Food charts reviewed - intake appears adequate but fluctuating. GP referral made urgently. Dietitian input requested. Possible causes being investigated - dental problems, infection, medication side effects, low mood. Daily food and fluid monitoring implemented. Fortified diet commenced. Family informed and concerned - will visit to encourage eating. MUST score calculated - medium risk.

Service user refused all morning medications in Wet Room stating 'I don't need them'. Staff attempted gentle persuasion explaining importance of medication but service user became agitated. Decision made not to force medication to maintain relationship. Senior staff informed. Further attempt made 1 hour later by different staff member - medications accepted without issue. Mental capacity regarding medication decisions to be reviewed. GP aware.

Routine monthly weighing in Entrance Hall showed service user has lost 4kg in past month (current weight 52kg). Senior staff informed. Food charts reviewed - intake appears adequate but fluctuating. GP referral made urgently. Dietitian input requested. Possible causes being investigated - dental problems, infection, medication side effects, low mood. Daily food and fluid monitoring implemented. Fortified diet commenced. Family informed and concerned - will visit to encourage eating. MUST score calculated - medium risk.

Service user began choking while eating lunch in Outside Patio. Staff member immediately intervened, encouraged coughing. Obstruction cleared after 3-4 strong coughs. Service user recovered quickly, breathing normally. Remained seated and observed for 15 minutes. No respiratory distress noted. Meal discontinued as precaution. SALT referral made urgently. Swallowing assessment to be completed before resuming normal diet. Soft diet and supervision implemented meanwhile. GP informed. Family contacted.

Broken window pane discovered in Corridor during morning checks. Small crack in outer pane, no glass fragments in room. Cause unknown - possibly weather related. Area made safe, room secured and not in use pending repair. Maintenance informed. Emergency glazier contacted - repair scheduled for today. No injuries, no service users in room at time of discovery. All windows to be inspected as precaution. Manager notified.

Service user noted missing from Garden during routine check. Search of building commenced immediately. Not found on premises. CCTV checked - showed service user leaving via main entrance 15 minutes earlier. Police contacted immediately and description provided. Family informed. Staff member searched local area in vehicle. Police located service user 2 streets away, unharmed but confused. Returned to service safely. Full assessment completed - no injuries, appeared well. Mental capacity assessment to be completed. Door security system reviewed. Safeguarding alert raised. Best interest meeting arranged.

Broken window pane discovered in Bedroom during morning checks. Small crack in outer pane, no glass fragments in room. Cause unknown - possibly weather related. Area made safe, room secured and not in use pending repair. Maintenance informed. Emergency glazier contacted - repair scheduled for today. No injuries, no service users in room at time of discovery. All windows to be inspected as precaution. Manager notified.

After 20 minutes, approached by familiar staff member with cup of tea. Service user accepted drink and appeared calmer. Personal care reattempted with different approach - service user cooperative. Trigger appeared to be rushing and feeling pressured. ABC chart completed. Reminder to all staff to allow extra time and not to rush. Service user's preferred routine discussed at handover.

Service user reported to staff in Bedroom that another service user 'took money from their room'. Senior staff informed immediately. Both service users spoken to separately. Room checked with service user - all belongings accounted for, no money missing. Service user appeared confused about allegation and later could not recall making it. Possible confabulation due to dementia. Documented as potential safeguarding concern. Manager informed, monitoring in place. Family updated. Valuables list checked - all items present.

brief_description: Exit-seeking behaviour - attempted to leave building
body_text: Service user found at front entrance in Outside Patio attempting to open the door stating they needed to 'get home to cook dinner'. Gently redirected by staff using distraction technique. Offered cup of tea and biscuit which was accepted. Walked with staff to lounge where familiar music was playing. Became settled and engaged in conversation about past. Appeared to forget about leaving. Family member telephoned to provide reassurance which helped. No distress caused. Security settings on door checked and functioning correctly.

Tablet (later identified as Amlodipine 5mg) found on floor in Entrance Hall during cleaning. Unable to determine which service user this belonged to. All service users in area checked - all MAR charts showed medications signed as given. Tablet disposed of as per policy. All staff reminded to observe service users swallowing medications. Medication administration procedures reviewed with team.

During assisted transfer from wheelchair to armchair in Main Lounge, service user's legs gave way. Staff member supported controlled descent to floor, preventing injury. Service user assessed on floor - no pain or obvious injury. Assistance requested, two staff used hoist to transfer to bed for full assessment. Appeared shaken but no injuries sustained. Observations normal. Encouraged to rest. Physiotherapy referral made for mobility review.

brief_description: Verbal aggression towards staff during personal care
body_text: During morning personal care in Garden, service user became verbally aggressive, shouting and swearing at care staff. Staff member stepped back, gave space, and spoke calmly. Service user continued to refuse care. Staff left room for 10 minutes then returned with different colleague. Service user had calmed and accepted care from new staff member. Possible triggers: overtired, preferred male carer not available. ABC chart completed. Behaviour support plan reviewed - no changes needed. Service user later apologised to staff.

brief_description: Physical aggression - grabbed staff member's arm
body_text: While providing assistance in Main Lounge, service user suddenly grabbed staff member's left forearm tightly. Staff member remained calm, asked service user to let go, which they did after approximately 5 seconds. Small red mark visible on staff arm but no broken skin. Cold compress applied, mark faded within 30 minutes. Service user appeared confused and did not recognise what had happened. Possible pain trigger - appeared to grimace when moved. PRN analgesia offered and accepted. Behaviour settled. No injury to staff member. Staff member completed incident form and body map.

During personal care in Quiet Lounge, staff member noticed several bruises to upper arms (approximately 2-3cm each, yellow/green in colour). Service user unable to explain how bruises occurred. Body map completed and photographed. Senior staff informed immediately. Safeguarding alert raised as per policy. Recent visitors and activities reviewed. No concerns identified but monitoring continues. Family contacted - unaware of any incidents. Safeguarding team to investigate. Service user observed for any further marks or changes in behaviour.

brief_description: Physical aggression - grabbed staff member's arm
body_text: While providing assistance in Entrance Hall, service user suddenly grabbed staff member's left forearm tightly. Staff member remained calm, asked service user to let go, which they did after approximately 5 seconds. Small red mark visible on staff arm but no broken skin. Cold compress applied, mark faded within 30 minutes. Service user appeared confused and did not recognise what had happened. Possible pain trigger - appeared to grimace when moved. PRN analgesia offered and accepted. Behaviour settled. No injury to staff member. Staff member completed incident form and body map.

Water leak discovered in ceiling of Entrance Hall during routine checks. Area immediately cordoned off, service users moved to alternative location. Maintenance contacted - attended within 30 minutes. Leak from bathroom above identified and isolated. Ceiling assessed - no immediate collapse risk but requires repair. Room out of use until repairs completed. Manager informed, contractors arranged for tomorrow. No service users or staff affected. All equipment removed from room.

brief_description: Exit-seeking behaviour - attempted to leave building
body_text: Service user found at front entrance in Day Room attempting to open the door stating they needed to 'get home to cook dinner'. Gently redirected by staff using distraction technique. Offered cup of tea and biscuit which was accepted. Walked with staff to lounge where familiar music was playing. Became settled and engaged in conversation about past. Appeared to forget about leaving. Family member telephoned to provide reassurance which helped. No distress caused. Security settings on door checked and functioning correctly.

During personal care in Corridor, care staff noticed 3cm skin tear to right forearm. Service user stated they must have caught it on wheelchair but couldn't remember when. Wound cleaned with saline, sterile dressing applied as per tissue viability protocol. Wound photographed and body map completed. Not infected, edges well approximated. District nurse informed - will review at next visit. Skin tear risk assessment updated. Long sleeves recommended to protect fragile skin.

Routine monthly weighing in Bathroom showed service user has lost 4kg in past month (current weight 52kg). Senior staff informed. Food charts reviewed - intake appears adequate but fluctuating. GP referral made urgently. Dietitian input requested. Possible causes being investigated - dental problems, infection, medication side effects, low mood. Daily food and fluid monitoring implemented. Fortified diet commenced. Family informed and concerned - will visit to encourage eating. MUST score calculated - medium risk.

Service user noted missing from Entrance Hall during routine check. Search of building commenced immediately. Not found on premises. brief_description: Service user found on floor in Conservatory
body_text: Staff member entered Conservatory at 04:47 and found service user sitting on the floor. Service user stated they had been reaching for their walking frame and lost balance. No visible injuries noted. Vital signs checked and within normal limits. Neurological observations commenced as per falls protocol. Service user assisted to chair with hoist. Comfortable and alert. Family notified. Incident form completed. GP informed - no further action required at this time.

All windows to be inspected as precaution. Manager notified.

Tablet (later identified as Amlodipine 5mg) found on floor in Wet Room during cleaning. Unable to determine which service user this belonged to. All service users in area checked - all MAR charts showed medications signed as given. Tablet disposed of as per policy. All staff reminded to observe service users swallowing medications. Medication administration procedures reviewed with team.

Service user refused all morning medications in Entrance Hall stating 'I don't need them'. Staff attempted gentle persuasion explaining importance of medication but service user became agitated. Decision made not to force medication to maintain relationship. Senior staff informed. Further attempt made 1 hour later by different staff member - medications accepted without issue. Mental capacity regarding medication decisions to be reviewed. GP aware.

Service user began choking while eating lunch in Entrance Hall. Staff member immediately intervened, encouraged coughing. Obstruction cleared after 3-4 strong coughs. Service user recovered quickly, breathing normally. Remained seated and observed for 15 minutes. No respiratory distress noted. Meal discontinued as precaution. SALT referral made urgently. Swallowing assessment to be completed before resuming normal diet. Soft diet and supervision implemented meanwhile. GP informed. Family contacted.

Service user became resistive during personal care in Entrance Hall, pushing staff away and shouting. Care abandoned immediately. Service user left to calm with regular checks from doorway. Service user experienced tonic-clonic seizure in Wet Room lasting approximately 2 minutes. Staff protected head with cushion, cleared area, timed seizure, placed in recovery position once jerking stopped. Post-ictal period - confused and drowsy for approximately 20 minutes. Vital signs monitored and stable. Known epilepsy, last seizure 6 months ago. No injuries sustained during seizure. Recovery uneventful. GP contacted - medication review arranged. Detailed seizure record completed. Neurological observations continued for 4 hours post-seizure.

Appeared to forget about leaving. Family member telephoned to provide reassurance which helped. No distress caused. Security settings on door checked and functioning correctly.

Service user reported to staff in Outside Patio that another service user 'took money from their room'. Senior staff informed immediately. Both service users spoken to separately. Room checked with service user - all belongings accounted for, no money missing. Service user appeared confused about allegation and later could not recall making it. Possible confabulation due to dementia. Documented as potential safeguarding concern. Manager informed, monitoring in place. Family updated. Valuables list checked - all items present.

Broken window pane discovered in Main Lounge during morning checks. Small crack in outer pane, no glass fragments in room. Cause unknown - possibly weather related. Area made safe, room secured and not in use pending repair. Maintenance informed. Emergency glazier contacted - repair scheduled for today. No injuries, no service users in room at time of discovery. All windows to be inspected as precaution. Manager notified.

During personal care in Entrance Hall, care staff noticed 3cm skin tear to right forearm. Service user stated they must have caught it on wheelchair but couldn't remember when. Wound cleaned with saline, sterile dressing applied as per tissue viability protocol. Wound photographed and body map completed. Not infected, edges well approximated. District nurse informed - will review at next visit. Skin tear risk assessment updated. Long sleeves recommended to protect fragile skin.

During personal care in Corridor, staff member noticed several bruises to upper arms (approximately 2-3cm each, yellow/green in colour). Service user unable to explain how bruises occurred. Body map completed and photographed. Senior staff informed immediately. Safeguarding alert raised as per policy. Recent visitors and activities reviewed. No concerns identified but monitoring continues. Family contacted - unaware of any incidents. Safeguarding team to investigate. Service user observed for any further marks or changes in behaviour.

body_text: Service user found at front entrance in Wet Room attempting to open the door stating they needed to 'get home to cook dinner'. Gently redirected by staff using distraction technique. Appeared to forget about leaving. Family member telephoned to provide reassurance which helped. No distress caused. Security settings on door checked and functioning correctly.

Service user became resistive during personal care in Wet Room, pushing staff away and shouting. Care abandoned immediately. Service user left to calm with regular checks from doorway. After 20 minutes, approached by familiar staff member with cup of tea. Service user accepted drink and appeared calmer. Personal care reattempted with different approach - service user cooperative. Trigger appeared to be rushing and feeling pressured. ABC chart completed. Reminder to all staff to allow extra time and not to rush. Service user's preferred routine discussed at handover.

Routine monthly weighing in Wet Room showed service user has lost 4kg in past month (current weight 52kg). Senior staff informed. Food charts reviewed - intake appears adequate but fluctuating. GP referral made urgently. Dietitian input requested. Possible causes being investigated - dental problems, infection, medication side effects, low mood. Daily food and fluid monitoring implemented. Fortified diet commenced. Family informed and concerned - will visit to encourage eating. MUST score calculated - medium risk.

brief_description: Physical aggression - grabbed staff member's arm
body_text: While providing assistance in Bedroom, service user suddenly grabbed staff member's left forearm tightly. Staff member remained calm, asked service user to let go, which they did after approximately 5 seconds. Small red mark visible on staff arm but no broken skin. Cold compress applied, mark faded within 30 minutes. Service user appeared confused and did not recognise what had happened. Possible pain trigger - appeared to grimace when moved. PRN analgesia offered and accepted. Behaviour settled. No injury to staff member. Staff member completed incident form and body map.

Service user became resistive during personal care in Kitchen, pushing staff away and shouting. Care abandoned immediately. Service user left to calm with regular checks from doorway. After 20 minutes, approached by familiar staff member with cup of tea. Service user accepted drink and appeared calmer. Personal care reattempted with different approach - service user cooperative. Trigger appeared to be rushing and feeling pressured. ABC chart completed. Reminder to all staff to allow extra time and not to rush. Service user's preferred routine discussed at handover.

Service user discovered on floor in Garden by care staff during routine checks. Fall was unwitnessed. Service user unable to recall what happened but complained of pain to right hip. Left in position, emergency services called. Paramedics attended and conveyed to A&E for assessment. X-ray confirmed no fracture. Returned to service later same day. Post-falls protocol initiated. Family updated throughout. Falls risk assessment reviewed.

All windows to be inspected as precaution. Manager notified.

Service user noted missing from Main Lounge during routine check. Search of building commenced immediately. Not found on premises. CCTV checked - showed service user leaving via main entrance 15 minutes earlier. Police contacted immediately and description provided. Family informed. Staff member searched local area in vehicle. Police located service user 2 streets away, unharmed but confused. Returned to service safely. Full assessment completed - no injuries, appeared well. Mental capacity assessment to be completed. Door security system reviewed. Safeguarding alert raised. Best interest meeting arranged.

brief_description: Verbal aggression towards staff during personal care
body_text: During morning personal care in Wet Room, service user became verbally aggressive, shouting and swearing at care staff. Staff member stepped back, gave space, and spoke calmly. Service user continued to refuse care. Staff left room for 10 minutes then returned with different colleague. Service user had calmed and accepted care from new staff member. Possible triggers: overtired, preferred male carer not available. ABC chart completed. Behaviour support plan reviewed - no changes needed. Service user later apologised to staff.

brief_description: Service user found on floor in Dining Room
body_text: Staff member entered Dining Room at 07:01 and found service user sitting on the floor. Service user stated they had been reaching for their walking frame and lost balance. No visible injuries noted. Vital signs checked and within normal limits. Neurological observations commenced as per falls protocol. Service user assisted to chair with hoist. Comfortable and alert. Family notified. Incident form completed. GP informed - no further action required at this time.

Service user noted missing from Bedroom during routine check. Search of building commenced immediately. Not found on premises. CCTV checked - showed service user leaving via main entrance 15 minutes earlier. Police contacted immediately and description provided. Family informed. Staff member searched local area in vehicle. Police located service user 2 streets away, unharmed but confused. Returned to service safely. Full assessment completed - no injuries, appeared well. Mental capacity assessment to be completed. Door security system reviewed. Safeguarding alert raised. Best interest meeting arranged.

Service user refused all morning medications in Activity Room stating 'I don't need them'. Staff attempted gentle persuasion explaining importance of medication but service user became agitated. Decision made not to force medication to maintain relationship. Senior staff informed. Further attempt made 1 hour later by different staff member - medications accepted without issue. Mental capacity regarding medication decisions to be reviewed. GP aware.

body_text: Service user found at front entrance in Conservatory attempting to open the door stating they needed to 'get home to cook dinner'. Gently redirected by staff using distraction technique. Offered cup of tea and biscuit which was accepted. Walked with staff to lounge where familiar music was playing. Became settled and engaged in conversation about past. Appeared to forget about leaving. Family member telephoned to provide reassurance which helped. No distress caused. Security settings on door checked and functioning correctly.

During personal care in Activity Room, staff member noticed several bruises to upper arms (approximately 2-3cm each, yellow/green in colour). Service user unable to explain how bruises occurred. Body map completed and photographed. Senior staff informed immediately. Safeguarding alert raised as per policy. Recent visitors and activities reviewed. No concerns identified but monitoring continues. Family contacted - unaware of any incidents. Safeguarding team to investigate. Service user observed for any further marks or changes in behaviour.

Service user reported to staff in Day Room that another service user 'took money from their room'. Senior staff informed immediately. Both service users spoken to separately. Room checked with service user - all belongings accounted for, no money missing. Service user appeared confused about allegation and later could not recall making it. Possible confabulation due to dementia. Documented as potential safeguarding concern. Manager informed, monitoring in place. Family updated. Valuables list checked - all items present.

Service user experienced tonic-clonic seizure in Day Room lasting approximately 2 minutes. Staff protected head with cushion, cleared area, timed seizure, placed in recovery position once jerking stopped. Post-ictal period - confused and drowsy for approximately 20 minutes. Vital signs monitored and stable. Known epilepsy, last seizure 6 months ago. No injuries sustained during seizure. Recovery uneventful. GP contacted - medication review arranged. Detailed seizure record completed. Neurological observations continued for 4 hours post-seizure.

During assisted transfer from wheelchair to armchair in Dining Room, service user's legs gave way. Staff member supported controlled descent to floor, preventing injury. Service user assessed on floor - no pain or obvious injury. Assistance requested, two staff used hoist to transfer to bed for full assessment. Appeared shaken but no injuries sustained. Observations normal. Encouraged to rest. Physiotherapy referral made for mobility review.

Redness noted to sacral area during personal care in Outside Patio. Area measures approximately 2cm x 2cm, non-blanching. Service user denies pain or discomfort. Repositioning schedule reviewed and increased to 2-hourly. Barrier cream applied. Pressure-relieving cushion in use. Nutrition reviewed - adequate intake. District nurse to assess within 24 hours. Photography and body mapping completed. Waterlow score recalculated - remains high risk. Tissue viability nurse referral made.

brief_description: Service user found on floor in Bathroom
body_text: Staff member entered Bathroom at 23:32 and found service user sitting on the floor. Service user stated they had been reaching for their walking frame and lost balance. No visible injuries noted. Vital signs checked and within normal limits. Neurological observations commenced as per falls protocol. Service user assisted to chair with hoist. Comfortable and alert. Family notified. Incident form completed. GP informed - no further action required at this time.

Service user refused all morning medications in Quiet Lounge stating 'I don't need them'. Staff attempted gentle persuasion explaining importance of medication but service user became agitated. Decision made not to force medication to maintain relationship. Senior staff informed. Further attempt made 1 hour later by different staff member - medications accepted without issue. Mental capacity regarding medication decisions to be reviewed. GP aware.

brief_description: Physical aggression - grabbed staff member's arm
body_text: While providing assistance in Day Room, service user suddenly grabbed staff member's left forearm tightly. Staff member remained calm, asked service user to let go, which they did after approximately 5 seconds. Small red mark visible on staff arm but no broken skin. Cold compress applied, mark faded within 30 minutes. Service user appeared confused and did not recognise what had happened. Possible pain trigger - appeared to grimace when moved. PRN analgesia offered and accepted. Behaviour settled. No injury to staff member. Staff member completed incident form and body map.

brief_description: Physical aggression - grabbed staff member's arm
body_text: While providing assistance in Conservatory, service user suddenly grabbed staff member's left forearm tightly. Staff member remained calm, asked service user to let go, which they did after approximately 5 seconds. Small red mark visible on staff arm but no broken skin. Cold compress applied, mark faded within 30 minutes. Service user appeared confused and did not recognise what had happened. Possible pain trigger - appeared to grimace when moved. PRN analgesia offered and accepted. Behaviour settled. No injury to staff member. Staff member completed incident form and body map.

All windows to be inspected as precaution. Manager notified.

brief_description: Exit-seeking behaviour - attempted to leave building
body_text: Service user found at front entrance in Bedroom attempting to open the door stating they needed to 'get home to cook dinner'. Gently redirected by staff using distraction technique. Offered cup of tea and biscuit which was accepted. Walked with staff to lounge where familiar music was playing. Became settled and engaged in conversation about past. Appeared to forget about leaving. Family member telephoned to provide reassurance which helped. No distress caused. Security settings on door checked and functioning correctly.

brief_description: Physical aggression - grabbed staff member's arm
body_text: While providing assistance in Outside Patio, service user suddenly grabbed staff member's left forearm tightly. Staff member remained calm, asked service user to let go, which they did after approximately 5 seconds. Small red mark visible on staff arm but no broken skin. Cold compress applied, mark faded within 30 minutes. Service user appeared confused and did not recognise what had happened. Possible pain trigger - appeared to grimace when moved. PRN analgesia offered and accepted. Behaviour settled. No injury to staff member. Staff member completed incident form and body map.

Service user began choking while eating lunch in Day Room. Staff member immediately intervened, encouraged coughing. Obstruction cleared after 3-4 strong coughs. Swallowing assessment to be completed before resuming normal diet. Soft diet and supervision implemented meanwhile. GP informed. Family contacted.

brief_description: Verbal aggression towards staff during personal care
body_text: During morning personal care in Dining Room, service user became verbally aggressive, shouting and swearing at care staff. Staff member stepped back, gave space, and spoke calmly. Service user continued to refuse care. Staff left room for 10 minutes then returned with different colleague. Service user had calmed and accepted care from new staff member. Possible triggers: overtired, preferred male carer not available. ABC chart completed. Behaviour support plan reviewed - no changes needed. Service user later apologised to staff.

brief_description: Exit-seeking behaviour - attempted to leave building
body_text: Service user found at front entrance in Corridor attempting to open the door stating they needed to 'get home to cook dinner'. Gently redirected by staff using distraction technique. Offered cup of tea and biscuit which was accepted. Walked with staff to lounge where familiar music was playing. Became settled and engaged in conversation about past. Appeared to forget about leaving. Family member telephoned to provide reassurance which helped. No distress caused. Security settings on door checked and functioning correctly.

Service user became resistive during personal care in Main Lounge, pushing staff away and shouting. Care abandoned immediately. Service user left to calm with regular checks from doorway. After 20 minutes, approached by familiar staff member with cup of tea. Service user accepted drink and appeared calmer. Personal care reattempted with different approach - service user cooperative. Trigger appeared to be rushing and feeling pressured. ABC chart completed. Reminder to all staff to allow extra time and not to rush. Service user's preferred routine discussed at handover.

Photography and body mapping completed. Waterlow score recalculated - remains high risk. Tissue viability nurse referral made.

Service user noted missing from Bathroom during routine check. Search of building commenced immediately. Not found on premises. CCTV checked - showed service user leaving via main entrance 15 minutes earlier. Police contacted immediately and description provided. Family informed. Staff member searched local area in vehicle. Police located service user 2 streets away, unharmed but confused. Returned to service safely. Full assessment completed - no injuries, appeared well. Mental capacity assessment to be completed. Door security system reviewed. Safeguarding alert raised. Best interest meeting arranged.

No concerns identified but monitoring continues. Family contacted - unaware of any incidents. Safeguarding team to investigate. Service user observed for any further marks or changes in behaviour.

GP contacted and advised continued monitoring. Families informed and apologised to. Staff member retrained on checking procedures. Incident reviewed at clinical governance meeting.

Service user noted missing from Outside Patio during routine check. Search of building commenced immediately. Not found on premises. CCTV checked - showed service user leaving via main entrance 15 minutes earlier. Police contacted immediately and description provided. Family informed. Staff member searched local area in vehicle. Police located service user 2 streets away, unharmed but confused. Returned to service safely. Full assessment completed - no injuries, appeared well. Mental capacity assessment to be completed. Door security system reviewed. Safeguarding alert raised. Best interest meeting arranged.

Service user refused all morning medications in Kitchen stating 'I don't need them'. Staff attempted gentle persuasion explaining importance of medication but service user became agitated. Decision made not to force medication to maintain relationship. Senior staff informed. Further attempt made 1 hour later by different staff member - medications accepted without issue. Mental capacity regarding medication decisions to be reviewed. GP aware.

Service user discovered on floor in Conservatory by care staff during routine checks. Fall was unwitnessed. Service user unable to recall what happened but complained of pain to right hip. Left in position, emergency services called. Paramedics attended and conveyed to A&E for assessment. X-ray confirmed no fracture. Returned to service later same day. Post-falls protocol initiated. Family updated throughout. Falls risk assessment reviewed.

Service user became resistive during personal care in Bedroom, pushing staff away and shouting. Care abandoned immediately. Service user left to calm with regular checks from doorway. After 20 minutes, approached by familiar staff member with cup of tea. Service user accepted drink and appeared calmer. Personal care reattempted with different approach - service user cooperative. Trigger appeared to be rushing and feeling pressured. ABC chart completed. Reminder to all staff to allow extra time and not to rush. Service user's preferred routine discussed at handover.

Door security system reviewed. Safeguarding alert raised. Best interest meeting arranged.

Service user experienced tonic-clonic seizure in Conservatory lasting approximately 2 minutes. Staff protected head with cushion, cleared area, timed seizure, placed in recovery position once jerking stopped. Post-ictal period - confused and drowsy for approximately 20 minutes. Vital signs monitored and stable. Known epilepsy, last seizure 6 months ago. No injuries sustained during seizure. Recovery uneventful. GP contacted - medication review arranged. Detailed seizure record completed. Neurological observations continued for 4 hours post-seizure.

During medication round in Entrance Hall, staff member realised they had administered morning medications to incorrect service user. Error identified immediately. GP contacted and advised continued monitoring. Families informed and apologised to. Staff member retrained on checking procedures. Incident reviewed at clinical governance meeting.

Broken window pane discovered in Corridor during morning checks. Small crack in outer pane, no glass fragments in room. Cause unknown - possibly weather related. Area made safe, room secured and not in use pending repair. Maintenance informed. Emergency glazier contacted - repair scheduled for today. No injuries, no service users in room at time of discovery. All windows to be inspected as precaution. Manager notified.

Routine monthly weighing in Conservatory showed service user has lost 4kg in past month (current weight 52kg). Senior staff informed. Food charts reviewed - intake appears adequate but fluctuating. GP referral made urgently. Dietitian input requested. Possible causes being investigated - dental problems, infection, medication side effects, low mood. Daily food and fluid monitoring implemented. Fortified diet commenced. Family informed and concerned - will visit to encourage eating. MUST score calculated - medium risk.

Water leak discovered in ceiling of Dining Room during routine checks. Area immediately cordoned off, service users moved to alternative location. Maintenance contacted - attended within 30 minutes. Leak from bathroom above identified and isolated. Ceiling assessed - no immediate collapse risk but requires repair. Room out of use until repairs completed. Manager informed, contractors arranged for tomorrow. No service users or staff affected. All equipment removed from room.

brief_description: Exit-seeking behaviour - attempted to leave building
body_text: Service user found at front entrance in Conservatory attempting to open the door stating they needed to 'get home to cook dinner'. Gently redirected by staff using distraction technique. Offered cup of tea and biscuit which was accepted. Walked with staff to lounge where familiar music was playing. Became settled and engaged in conversation about past. Appeared to forget about leaving. Family member telephoned to provide reassurance which helped. No distress caused. Security settings on door checked and functioning correctly.

brief_description: Physical aggression - grabbed staff member's arm
body_text: While providing assistance in Activity Room, service user suddenly grabbed staff member's left forearm tightly. Staff member remained calm, asked service user to let go, which they did after approximately 5 seconds. Small red mark visible on staff arm but no broken skin. Cold compress applied, mark faded within 30 minutes. Service user appeared confused and did not recognise what had happened. Possible pain trigger - appeared to grimace when moved. PRN analgesia offered and accepted. Behaviour settled. No injury to staff member. Staff member completed incident form and body map.

Service user reported to staff in Corridor that another service user 'took money from their room'. Senior staff informed immediately. Both service users spoken to separately. Room checked with service user - all belongings accounted for, no money missing. Service user appeared confused about allegation and later could not recall making it. Possible confabulation due to dementia. Documented as potential safeguarding concern. Manager informed, monitoring in place. Family updated. Valuables list checked - all items present.

Service user began choking while eating lunch in Corridor. Staff member immediately intervened, encouraged coughing. Obstruction cleared after 3-4 strong coughs. Service user recovered quickly, breathing normally. Remained seated and observed for 15 minutes. No respiratory distress noted. Meal discontinued as precaution. SALT referral made urgently. Swallowing assessment to be completed before resuming normal diet. Soft diet and supervision implemented meanwhile. GP informed. Family contacted.

Service user refused all morning medications in Conservatory stating 'I don't need them'. Staff attempted gentle persuasion explaining importance of medication but service user became agitated. Decision made not to force medication to maintain relationship. Senior staff informed. Further attempt made 1 hour later by different staff member - medications accepted without issue. Mental capacity regarding medication decisions to be reviewed. GP aware.

brief_description: Physical aggression - grabbed staff member's arm
body_text: While providing assistance in Entrance Hall, service user suddenly grabbed staff member's left forearm tightly. Staff member remained calm, asked service user to let go, which they did after approximately 5 seconds. Small red mark visible on staff arm but no broken skin. Cold compress applied, mark faded within 30 minutes. Service user appeared confused and did not recognise what had happened. Possible pain trigger - appeared to grimace when moved. PRN analgesia offered and accepted. Behaviour settled. No injury to staff member. Staff member completed incident form and body map.

Service user became resistive during personal care in Corridor, pushing staff away and shouting. Care abandoned immediately. Service user left to calm with regular checks from doorway. After 20 minutes, approached by familiar staff member with cup of tea. Service user accepted drink and appeared calmer. Personal care reattempted with different approach - service user cooperative. Trigger appeared to be rushing and feeling pressured. ABC chart completed. Reminder to all staff to allow extra time and not to rush. Service user's preferred routine discussed at handover.

Service user noted missing from Corridor during routine check. Search of building commenced immediately. Not found on premises. CCTV checked - showed service user leaving via main entrance 15 minutes earlier. Police contacted immediately and description provided. Family informed. Staff member searched local area in vehicle. Police located service user 2 streets away, unharmed but confused. Returned to service safely. Full assessment completed - no injuries, appeared well. Mental capacity assessment to be completed. Door security system reviewed. Safeguarding alert raised. Best interest meeting arranged.

Broken window pane discovered in Corridor during morning checks. Small crack in outer pane, no glass fragments in room. Cause unknown - possibly weather related. Area made safe, room secured and not in use pending repair. Maintenance informed. Emergency glazier contacted - repair scheduled for today. No injuries, no service users in room at time of discovery. All windows to be inspected as precaution. Manager notified.

Water leak discovered in ceiling of Conservatory during routine checks. Area immediately cordoned off, service users moved to alternative location. Maintenance contacted - attended within 30 minutes. Leak from bathroom above identified and isolated. Ceiling assessed - no immediate collapse risk but requires repair. Room out of use until repairs completed. Manager informed, contractors arranged for tomorrow. No service users or staff affected. All equipment removed from room.

Tablet (later identified as Amlodipine 5mg) found on floor in Bedroom during cleaning. Unable to determine which service user this belonged to. All service users in area checked - all MAR charts showed medications signed as given. Tablet disposed of as per policy. All staff reminded to observe service users swallowing medications. Medication administration procedures reviewed with team.

brief_description: Exit-seeking behaviour - attempted to leave building
body_text: Service user found at front entrance in Bedroom attempting to open the door stating they needed to 'get home to cook dinner'. Gently redirected by staff using distraction technique. Service user experienced tonic-clonic seizure in Day Room lasting approximately 2 minutes. Staff protected head with cushion, cleared area, timed seizure, placed in recovery position once jerking stopped. Post-ictal period - confused and drowsy for approximately 20 minutes. Vital signs monitored and stable. Known epilepsy, last seizure 6 months ago. No injuries sustained during seizure. Recovery uneventful. GP contacted - medication review arranged. Detailed seizure record completed. Neurological observations continued for 4 hours post-seizure.

Broken window pane discovered in Garden during morning checks. Small crack in outer pane, no glass fragments in room. Cause unknown - possibly weather related. Area made safe, room secured and not in use pending repair. Maintenance informed. Emergency glazier contacted - repair scheduled for today. No injuries, no service users in room at time of discovery. All windows to be inspected as precaution. Manager notified.

Routine monthly weighing in Garden showed service user has lost 4kg in past month (current weight 52kg). Senior staff informed. Food charts reviewed - intake appears adequate but fluctuating. GP referral made urgently. Dietitian input requested. Possible causes being investigated - dental problems, infection, medication side effects, low mood. Daily food and fluid monitoring implemented. Fortified diet commenced. Family informed and concerned - will visit to encourage eating. MUST score calculated - medium risk.

brief_description: Verbal aggression towards staff during personal care
body_text: During morning personal care in Quiet Lounge, service user became verbally aggressive, shouting and swearing at care staff. Staff member stepped back, gave space, and spoke calmly. Service user continued to refuse care. Staff left room for 10 minutes then returned with different colleague. Service user had calmed and accepted care from new staff member. Possible triggers: overtired, preferred male carer not available. ABC chart completed. Behaviour support plan reviewed - no changes needed. Service user later apologised to staff.

Service user refused all morning medications in Dining Room stating 'I don't need them'. Staff attempted gentle persuasion explaining importance of medication but service user became agitated. Decision made not to force medication to maintain relationship. Senior staff informed. Further attempt made 1 hour later by different staff member - medications accepted without issue. Mental capacity regarding medication decisions to be reviewed. GP aware.

Service user began choking while eating lunch in Outside Patio. Staff member immediately intervened, encouraged coughing. Obstruction cleared after 3-4 strong coughs. Service user recovered quickly, breathing normally. Remained seated and observed for 15 minutes. No respiratory distress noted. Meal discontinued as precaution. SALT referral made urgently. Swallowing assessment to be completed before resuming normal diet. Soft diet and supervision implemented meanwhile. GP informed. Family contacted.

All windows to be inspected as precaution. Manager notified.

Service user became resistive during personal care in Bedroom, pushing staff away and shouting. Care abandoned immediately. Service user left to calm with regular checks from doorway. brief_description: Exit-seeking behaviour - attempted to leave building
body_text: Service user found at front entrance in Entrance Hall attempting to open the door stating they needed to 'get home to cook dinner'. Gently redirected by staff using distraction technique. Offered cup of tea and biscuit which was accepted. Walked with staff to lounge where familiar music was playing. Became settled and engaged in conversation about past. Appeared to forget about leaving. Family member telephoned to provide reassurance which helped. No distress caused. Security settings on door checked and functioning correctly.

brief_description: Service user found on floor in Bedroom
body_text: Staff member entered Bedroom at 23:46 and found service user sitting on the floor. Service user stated they had been reaching for their walking frame and lost balance. No visible injuries noted. Vital signs checked and within normal limits. Neurological observations commenced as per falls protocol. Service user assisted to chair with hoist. Comfortable and alert. Family notified. Incident form completed. GP informed - no further action required at this time.

brief_description: Service user found on floor in Bedroom
body_text: Staff member entered Bedroom at 02:26 and found service user sitting on the floor. Service user stated they had been reaching for their walking frame and lost balance. No visible injuries noted. Vital signs checked and within normal limits. Neurological observations commenced as per falls protocol. Service user assisted to chair with hoist. Comfortable and alert. Family notified. Incident form completed. GP informed - no further action required at this time.

Broken window pane discovered in Conservatory during morning checks. Small crack in outer pane, no glass fragments in room. Cause unknown - possibly weather related. brief_description: Verbal aggression towards staff during personal care
body_text: During morning personal care in Main Lounge, service user became verbally aggressive, shouting and swearing at care staff. Staff member stepped back, gave space, and spoke calmly. Service user continued to refuse care. Staff left room for 10 minutes then returned with different colleague. Service user had calmed and accepted care from new staff member. Possible triggers: overtired, preferred male carer not available. ABC chart completed. Behaviour support plan reviewed - no changes needed. Service user later apologised to staff.

Detailed seizure record completed. Neurological observations continued for 4 hours post-seizure.

brief_description: Physical aggression - grabbed staff member's arm
body_text: While providing assistance in Garden, service user suddenly grabbed staff member's left forearm tightly. Staff member remained calm, asked service user to let go, which they did after approximately 5 seconds. Small red mark visible on staff arm but no broken skin. Cold compress applied, mark faded within 30 minutes. Service user appeared confused and did not recognise what had happened. Possible pain trigger - appeared to grimace when moved. PRN analgesia offered and accepted. Behaviour settled. No injury to staff member. Staff member completed incident form and body map.

brief_description: Exit-seeking behaviour - attempted to leave building
body_text: Service user found at front entrance in Conservatory attempting to open the door stating they needed to 'get home to cook dinner'. Gently redirected by staff using distraction technique. Offered cup of tea and biscuit which was accepted. Walked with staff to lounge where familiar music was playing. Became settled and engaged in conversation about past. Appeared to forget about leaving. Family member telephoned to provide reassurance which helped. No distress caused. Security settings on door checked and functioning correctly.

brief_description: Physical aggression - grabbed staff member's arm
body_text: While providing assistance in Outside Patio, service user suddenly grabbed staff member's left forearm tightly. Staff member remained calm, asked service user to let go, which they did after approximately 5 seconds. Small red mark visible on staff arm but no broken skin. Cold compress applied, mark faded within 30 minutes. Service user appeared confused and did not recognise what had happened. Possible pain trigger - appeared to grimace when moved. PRN analgesia offered and accepted. Behaviour settled. No injury to staff member. Staff member completed incident form and body map.

Service user experienced tonic-clonic seizure in Day Room lasting approximately 2 minutes. Staff protected head with cushion, cleared area, timed seizure, placed in recovery position once jerking stopped. Post-ictal period - confused and drowsy for approximately 20 minutes. Vital signs monitored and stable. Known epilepsy, last seizure 6 months ago. No injuries sustained during seizure. Recovery uneventful. GP contacted - medication review arranged. Detailed seizure record completed. Neurological observations continued for 4 hours post-seizure.

Routine monthly weighing in Entrance Hall showed service user has lost 4kg in past month (current weight 52kg). Senior staff informed. Food charts reviewed - intake appears adequate but fluctuating. GP referral made urgently. Dietitian input requested. Possible causes being investigated - dental problems, infection, medication side effects, low mood. Daily food and fluid monitoring implemented. Fortified diet commenced. Family informed and concerned - will visit to encourage eating. MUST score calculated - medium risk.

Service user became resistive during personal care in Outside Patio, pushing staff away and shouting. Care abandoned immediately. Service user left to calm with regular checks from doorway. After 20 minutes, approached by familiar staff member with cup of tea. Service user accepted drink and appeared calmer. Personal care reattempted with different approach - service user cooperative. Trigger appeared to be rushing and feeling pressured. ABC chart completed. Reminder to all staff to allow extra time and not to rush. Service user's preferred routine discussed at handover.

Service user noted missing from Dining Room during routine check. Search of building commenced immediately. Not found on premises. CCTV checked - showed service user leaving via main entrance 15 minutes earlier. Police contacted immediately and description provided. Family informed. Staff member searched local area in vehicle. Police located service user 2 streets away, unharmed but confused. Returned to service safely. Full assessment completed - no injuries, appeared well. Mental capacity assessment to be completed. Door security system reviewed. Safeguarding alert raised. Best interest meeting arranged.

Service user began choking while eating lunch in Entrance Hall. Staff member immediately intervened, encouraged coughing. Obstruction cleared after 3-4 strong coughs. Service user recovered quickly, breathing normally. Remained seated and observed for 15 minutes. No respiratory distress noted. Meal discontinued as precaution. SALT referral made urgently. Swallowing assessment to be completed before resuming normal diet. Soft diet and supervision implemented meanwhile. GP informed. Family contacted.

Broken window pane discovered in Main Lounge during morning checks. Small crack in outer pane, no glass fragments in room. Cause unknown - possibly weather related. Area made safe, room secured and not in use pending repair. Maintenance informed. Emergency glazier contacted - repair scheduled for today. No injuries, no service users in room at time of discovery. All windows to be inspected as precaution. Manager notified.

brief_description: Exit-seeking behaviour - attempted to leave building
body_text: Service user found at front entrance in Outside Patio attempting to open the door stating they needed to 'get home to cook dinner'. Gently redirected by staff using distraction technique. Offered cup of tea and biscuit which was accepted. Walked with staff to lounge where familiar music was playing. Became settled and engaged in conversation about past. Appeared to forget about leaving. Family member telephoned to provide reassurance which helped. No distress caused. Security settings on door checked and functioning correctly.

Service user noted missing from Conservatory during routine check. Search of building commenced immediately. Not found on premises. CCTV checked - showed service user leaving via main entrance 15 minutes earlier. Police contacted immediately and description provided. Family informed. Staff member searched local area in vehicle. Police located service user 2 streets away, unharmed but confused. Returned to service safely. Full assessment completed - no injuries, appeared well. Mental capacity assessment to be completed. Door security system reviewed. Safeguarding alert raised. Best interest meeting arranged.

Tablet (later identified as Amlodipine 5mg) found on floor in Corridor during cleaning. Unable to determine which service user this belonged to. All service users in area checked - all MAR charts showed medications signed as given. Tablet disposed of as per policy. All staff reminded to observe service users swallowing medications. Medication administration procedures reviewed with team.

Routine monthly weighing in Quiet Lounge showed service user has lost 4kg in past month (current weight 52kg). Senior staff informed. Food charts reviewed - intake appears adequate but fluctuating. GP referral made urgently. Dietitian input requested. Possible causes being investigated - dental problems, infection, medication side effects, low mood. Daily food and fluid monitoring implemented. Fortified diet commenced. Family informed and concerned - will visit to encourage eating. MUST score calculated - medium risk.

Service user noted missing from Entrance Hall during routine check. Search of building commenced immediately. Not found on premises. CCTV checked - showed service user leaving via main entrance 15 minutes earlier. Police contacted immediately and description provided. Family informed. Staff member searched local area in vehicle. Police located service user 2 streets away, unharmed but confused. Returned to service safely. Full assessment completed - no injuries, appeared well. Mental capacity assessment to be completed. Door security system reviewed. Safeguarding alert raised. Best interest meeting arranged.

Redness noted to sacral area during personal care in Corridor. Area measures approximately 2cm x 2cm, non-blanching. Service user denies pain or discomfort. Repositioning schedule reviewed and increased to 2-hourly. Barrier cream applied. Pressure-relieving cushion in use. Nutrition reviewed - adequate intake. District nurse to assess within 24 hours. Photography and body mapping completed. Waterlow score recalculated - remains high risk. Tissue viability nurse referral made.

brief_description: Verbal aggression towards staff during personal care
body_text: During morning personal care in Garden, service user became verbally aggressive, shouting and swearing at care staff. Staff member stepped back, gave space, and spoke calmly. Service user continued to refuse care. Staff left room for 10 minutes then returned with different colleague. Service user had calmed and accepted care from new staff member. Possible triggers: overtired, preferred male carer not available. ABC chart completed. Behaviour support plan reviewed - no changes needed. Service user later apologised to staff.

brief_description: Verbal aggression towards staff during personal care
body_text: During morning personal care in Entrance Hall, service user became verbally aggressive, shouting and swearing at care staff. Staff member stepped back, gave space, and spoke calmly. Service user continued to refuse care. Staff left room for 10 minutes then returned with different colleague. Service user had calmed and accepted care from new staff member. Possible triggers: overtired, preferred male carer not available. ABC chart completed. Behaviour support plan reviewed - no changes needed. Service user later apologised to staff.

During assisted transfer from wheelchair to armchair in Dining Room, service user's legs gave way. Staff member supported controlled descent to floor, preventing injury. Service user assessed on floor - no pain or obvious injury. Assistance requested, two staff used hoist to transfer to bed for full assessment. Appeared shaken but no injuries sustained. Observations normal. Encouraged to rest. Physiotherapy referral made for mobility review.

Water leak discovered in ceiling of Day Room during routine checks. Area immediately cordoned off, service users moved to alternative location. Maintenance contacted - attended within 30 minutes. Leak from bathroom above identified and isolated. Ceiling assessed - no immediate collapse risk but requires repair. Room out of use until repairs completed. Manager informed, contractors arranged for tomorrow. No service users or staff affected. All equipment removed from room.

Service user began choking while eating lunch in Quiet Lounge. Staff member immediately intervened, encouraged coughing. Obstruction cleared after 3-4 strong coughs. Service user recovered quickly, breathing normally. Remained seated and observed for 15 minutes. No respiratory distress noted. Meal discontinued as precaution. SALT referral made urgently. Swallowing assessment to be completed before resuming normal diet. Soft diet and supervision implemented meanwhile. GP informed. Family contacted.

Service user discovered on floor in Bedroom by care staff during routine checks. Fall was unwitnessed. Service user unable to recall what happened but complained of pain to right hip. Left in position, emergency services called. Paramedics attended and conveyed to A&E for assessment. X-ray confirmed no fracture. Returned to service later same day. Post-falls protocol initiated. Family updated throughout. Falls risk assessment reviewed.

Broken window pane discovered in Activity Room during morning checks. Small crack in outer pane, no glass fragments in room. Cause unknown - possibly weather related. All windows to be inspected as precaution. Manager notified.

Possible confabulation due to dementia. Documented as potential safeguarding concern. Manager informed, monitoring in place. Family updated. Valuables list checked - all items present.

brief_description: Physical aggression - grabbed staff member's arm
body_text: While providing assistance in Entrance Hall, service user suddenly grabbed staff member's left forearm tightly. Staff member remained calm, asked service user to let go, which they did after approximately 5 seconds. Small red mark visible on staff arm but no broken skin. Cold compress applied, mark faded within 30 minutes. Service user appeared confused and did not recognise what had happened. Possible pain trigger - appeared to grimace when moved. PRN analgesia offered and accepted. Behaviour settled. No injury to staff member. Staff member completed incident form and body map.

brief_description: Service user found on floor in Outside Patio
body_text: Staff member entered Outside Patio at 18:54 and found service user sitting on the floor. Service user stated they had been reaching for their walking frame and lost balance. No visible injuries noted. Vital signs checked and within normal limits. Neurological observations commenced as per falls protocol. Service user assisted to chair with hoist. Comfortable and alert. Family notified. Incident form completed. GP informed - no further action required at this time.
