All windows to be inspected as precaution. Manager notified.

Service user became resistive during personal care in Day Room, pushing staff away and shouting. Care abandoned immediately. Service user left to calm with regular checks from doorway. After 20 minutes, approached by familiar staff member with cup of tea. Service user accepted drink and appeared calmer. Personal care reattempted with different approach - service user cooperative. Trigger appeared to be rushing and feeling pressured. ABC chart completed. Reminder to all staff to allow extra time and not to rush. Service user's preferred routine discussed at handover.

Service user experienced tonic-clonic seizure in Day Room lasting approximately 2 minutes. Staff protected head with cushion, cleared area, timed seizure, placed in recovery position once jerking stopped. Post-ictal period - confused and drowsy for approximately 20 minutes. Vital signs monitored and stable. Known epilepsy, last seizure 6 months ago. No injuries sustained during seizure. Recovery uneventful. GP contacted - medication review arranged. Detailed seizure record completed. Neurological observations continued for 4 hours post-seizure.

brief_description: Exit-seeking behaviour - attempted to leave building
body_text: Service user found at front entrance in Kitchen attempting to open the door stating they needed to 'get home to cook dinner'. Gently redirected by staff using distraction technique. Offered cup of tea and biscuit which was accepted. Walked with staff to lounge where familiar music was playing. Became settled and engaged in conversation about past. Appeared to forget about leaving. Family member telephoned to provide reassurance which helped. No distress caused. Security settings on door checked and functioning correctly.

Service user reported to staff in Main Lounge that another service user 'took money from their room'. Senior staff informed immediately. Both service users spoken to separately. Room checked with service user - all belongings accounted for, no money missing. Service user appeared confused about allegation and later could not recall making it. Left in position, emergency services called. Paramedics attended and conveyed to A&E for assessment. X-ray confirmed no fracture. Returned to service later same day. Post-falls protocol initiated. Family updated throughout. Falls risk assessment reviewed.

During assisted transfer from wheelchair to armchair in Corridor, service user's legs gave way. Staff member supported controlled descent to floor, preventing injury. Service user assessed on floor - no pain or obvious injury. Assistance requested, two staff used hoist to transfer to bed for full assessment. Appeared shaken but no injuries sustained. Observations normal. Encouraged to rest. Physiotherapy referral made for mobility review.

During personal care in Bathroom, staff member noticed several bruises to upper arms (approximately 2-3cm each, yellow/green in colour). Service user unable to explain how bruises occurred. Body map completed and photographed. Senior staff informed immediately. Safeguarding alert raised as per policy. Recent visitors and activities reviewed. No concerns identified but monitoring continues. Family contacted - unaware of any incidents. Safeguarding team to investigate. Service user observed for any further marks or changes in behaviour.

Service user refused all morning medications in Quiet Lounge stating 'I don't need them'. Staff attempted gentle persuasion explaining importance of medication but service user became agitated. Decision made not to force medication to maintain relationship. Senior staff informed. Further attempt made 1 hour later by different staff member - medications accepted without issue. Mental capacity regarding medication decisions to be reviewed. GP aware.

brief_description: Service user found on floor in Garden
body_text: Staff member entered Garden at 18:56 and found service user sitting on the floor. Service user stated they had been reaching for their walking frame and lost balance. Family notified. Incident form completed. GP informed - no further action required at this time.

During assisted transfer from wheelchair to armchair in Bathroom, service user's legs gave way. Staff member supported controlled descent to floor, preventing injury. Service user assessed on floor - no pain or obvious injury. Assistance requested, two staff used hoist to transfer to bed for full assessment. Appeared shaken but no injuries sustained. Observations normal. Encouraged to rest. Physiotherapy referral made for mobility review.

Service user reported to staff in Entrance Hall that another service user 'took money from their room'. Senior staff informed immediately. Both service users spoken to separately. Possible confabulation due to dementia. Documented as potential safeguarding concern. Manager informed, monitoring in place. Family updated. Valuables list checked - all items present.

Fortified diet commenced. Family informed and concerned - will visit to encourage eating. MUST score calculated - medium risk.

Redness noted to sacral area during personal care in Main Lounge. Area measures approximately 2cm x 2cm, non-blanching. Service user denies pain or discomfort. Repositioning schedule reviewed and increased to 2-hourly. Barrier cream applied. Pressure-relieving cushion in use. Nutrition reviewed - adequate intake. District nurse to assess within 24 hours. Photography and body mapping completed. Waterlow score recalculated - remains high risk. Tissue viability nurse referral made.

Routine monthly weighing in Garden showed service user has lost 4kg in past month (current weight 52kg). Senior staff informed. Food charts reviewed - intake appears adequate but fluctuating. GP referral made urgently. Dietitian input requested. Possible causes being investigated - dental problems, infection, medication side effects, low mood. Daily food and fluid monitoring implemented. Fortified diet commenced. Family informed and concerned - will visit to encourage eating. MUST score calculated - medium risk.

Service user noted missing from Activity Room during routine check. Search of building commenced immediately. Not found on premises. CCTV checked - showed service user leaving via main entrance 15 minutes earlier. Police contacted immediately and description provided. Family informed. Staff member searched local area in vehicle. Police located service user 2 streets away, unharmed but confused. Returned to service safely. Full assessment completed - no injuries, appeared well. Mental capacity assessment to be completed. Door security system reviewed. Safeguarding alert raised. Best interest meeting arranged.

During personal care in Main Lounge, care staff noticed 3cm skin tear to right forearm. Service user stated they must have caught it on wheelchair but couldn't remember when. Wound cleaned with saline, sterile dressing applied as per tissue viability protocol. Wound photographed and body map completed. Not infected, edges well approximated. District nurse informed - will review at next visit. Skin tear risk assessment updated. Long sleeves recommended to protect fragile skin.

During assisted transfer from wheelchair to armchair in Outside Patio, service user's legs gave way. Staff member supported controlled descent to floor, preventing injury. Service user assessed on floor - no pain or obvious injury. Assistance requested, two staff used hoist to transfer to bed for full assessment. Appeared shaken but no injuries sustained. Observations normal. Encouraged to rest. Physiotherapy referral made for mobility review.

During personal care in Corridor, care staff noticed 3cm skin tear to right forearm. Service user stated they must have caught it on wheelchair but couldn't remember when. District nurse informed - will review at next visit. Skin tear risk assessment updated. Long sleeves recommended to protect fragile skin.

Trigger appeared to be rushing and feeling pressured. ABC chart completed. Reminder to all staff to allow extra time and not to rush. Service user's preferred routine discussed at handover.

During personal care in Main Lounge, staff member noticed several bruises to upper arms (approximately 2-3cm each, yellow/green in colour). Service user unable to explain how bruises occurred. Body map completed and photographed. Senior staff informed immediately. Safeguarding alert raised as per policy. Recent visitors and activities reviewed. No concerns identified but monitoring continues. Family contacted - unaware of any incidents. Safeguarding team to investigate. Service user observed for any further marks or changes in behaviour.

Service user reported to staff in Conservatory that another service user 'took money from their room'. Senior staff informed immediately. Both service users spoken to separately. Room checked with service user - all belongings accounted for, no money missing. Service user appeared confused about allegation and later could not recall making it. Possible confabulation due to dementia. Documented as potential safeguarding concern. Manager informed, monitoring in place. Family updated. Valuables list checked - all items present.

brief_description: Exit-seeking behaviour - attempted to leave building
body_text: Service user found at front entrance in Conservatory attempting to open the door stating they needed to 'get home to cook dinner'. Gently redirected by staff using distraction technique. Offered cup of tea and biscuit which was accepted. Walked with staff to lounge where familiar music was playing. Became settled and engaged in conversation about past. Appeared to forget about leaving. Family member telephoned to provide reassurance which helped. No distress caused. Security settings on door checked and functioning correctly.

Service user became resistive during personal care in Activity Room, pushing staff away and shouting. Care abandoned immediately. Service user left to calm with regular checks from doorway. After 20 minutes, approached by familiar staff member with cup of tea. Service user accepted drink and appeared calmer. Personal care reattempted with different approach - service user cooperative. Trigger appeared to be rushing and feeling pressured. ABC chart completed. Reminder to all staff to allow extra time and not to rush. Service user's preferred routine discussed at handover.

Service user experienced tonic-clonic seizure in Entrance Hall lasting approximately 2 minutes. Staff protected head with cushion, cleared area, timed seizure, placed in recovery position once jerking stopped. Post-ictal period - confused and drowsy for approximately 20 minutes. Vital signs monitored and stable. Known epilepsy, last seizure 6 months ago. No injuries sustained during seizure. Recovery uneventful. GP contacted - medication review arranged. Detailed seizure record completed. Neurological observations continued for 4 hours post-seizure.

During assisted transfer from wheelchair to armchair in Outside Patio, service user's legs gave way. Staff member supported controlled descent to floor, preventing injury. Service user assessed on floor - no pain or obvious injury. Assistance requested, two staff used hoist to transfer to bed for full assessment. Appeared shaken but no injuries sustained. Observations normal. Encouraged to rest. Physiotherapy referral made for mobility review.

During medication round in Conservatory, staff member realised they had administered morning medications to incorrect service user. Error identified immediately. Both service users' medications checked - no harmful medications swapped. Senior staff informed immediately, both service users monitored closely for next 4 hours. No adverse effects noted. GP contacted and advised continued monitoring. Families informed and apologised to. Staff member retrained on checking procedures. Incident reviewed at clinical governance meeting.

Swallowing assessment to be completed before resuming normal diet. Soft diet and supervision implemented meanwhile. GP informed. Family contacted.

brief_description: Verbal aggression towards staff during personal care
body_text: During morning personal care in Quiet Lounge, service user became verbally aggressive, shouting and swearing at care staff. Staff member stepped back, gave space, and spoke calmly. Service user continued to refuse care. Staff left room for 10 minutes then returned with different colleague. Service user had calmed and accepted care from new staff member. Possible triggers: overtired, preferred male carer not available. ABC chart completed. Behaviour support plan reviewed - no changes needed. Service user later apologised to staff.

Broken window pane discovered in Garden during morning checks. Small crack in outer pane, no glass fragments in room. Cause unknown - possibly weather related. Area made safe, room secured and not in use pending repair. Maintenance informed. Emergency glazier contacted - repair scheduled for today. No injuries, no service users in room at time of discovery. All windows to be inspected as precaution. Manager notified.

Tablet (later identified as Amlodipine 5mg) found on floor in Bathroom during cleaning. Unable to determine which service user this belonged to. All service users in area checked - all MAR charts showed medications signed as given. Tablet disposed of as per policy. All staff reminded to observe service users swallowing medications. Medication administration procedures reviewed with team.

Service user refused all morning medications in Outside Patio stating 'I don't need them'. Staff attempted gentle persuasion explaining importance of medication but service user became agitated. Decision made not to force medication to maintain relationship. Senior staff informed. Further attempt made 1 hour later by different staff member - medications accepted without issue. Mental capacity regarding medication decisions to be reviewed. GP aware.

Family updated throughout. Falls risk assessment reviewed.

Water leak discovered in ceiling of Quiet Lounge during routine checks. Area immediately cordoned off, service users moved to alternative location. Maintenance contacted - attended within 30 minutes. Leak from bathroom above identified and isolated. Ceiling assessed - no immediate collapse risk but requires repair. Room out of use until repairs completed. Manager informed, contractors arranged for tomorrow. No service users or staff affected. All equipment removed from room.

brief_description: Exit-seeking behaviour - attempted to leave building
body_text: Service user found at front entrance in Outside Patio attempting to open the door stating they needed to 'get home to cook dinner'. Gently redirected by staff using distraction technique. Offered cup of tea and biscuit which was accepted. Walked with staff to lounge where familiar music was playing. Became settled and engaged in conversation about past. Appeared to forget about leaving. Family member telephoned to provide reassurance which helped. No distress caused. Security settings on door checked and functioning correctly.

During personal care in Main Lounge, care staff noticed 3cm skin tear to right forearm. Service user stated they must have caught it on wheelchair but couldn't remember when. Wound cleaned with saline, sterile dressing applied as per tissue viability protocol. Wound photographed and body map completed. Not infected, edges well approximated. District nurse informed - will review at next visit. Skin tear risk assessment updated. Long sleeves recommended to protect fragile skin.

Routine monthly weighing in Garden showed service user has lost 4kg in past month (current weight 52kg). Senior staff informed. Food charts reviewed - intake appears adequate but fluctuating. GP referral made urgently. Dietitian input requested. Possible causes being investigated - dental problems, infection, medication side effects, low mood. Daily food and fluid monitoring implemented. Fortified diet commenced. Family informed and concerned - will visit to encourage eating. MUST score calculated - medium risk.

Redness noted to sacral area during personal care in Bedroom. Area measures approximately 2cm x 2cm, non-blanching. Service user denies pain or discomfort. Repositioning schedule reviewed and increased to 2-hourly. Barrier cream applied. Pressure-relieving cushion in use. Nutrition reviewed - adequate intake. District nurse to assess within 24 hours. Photography and body mapping completed. Waterlow score recalculated - remains high risk. Tissue viability nurse referral made.

During personal care in Dining Room, staff member noticed several bruises to upper arms (approximately 2-3cm each, yellow/green in colour). Service user unable to explain how bruises occurred. Body map completed and photographed. Senior staff informed immediately. Safeguarding alert raised as per policy. Recent visitors and activities reviewed. No concerns identified but monitoring continues. Family contacted - unaware of any incidents. Safeguarding team to investigate. Service user observed for any further marks or changes in behaviour.

Redness noted to sacral area during personal care in Entrance Hall. Area measures approximately 2cm x 2cm, non-blanching. Service user denies pain or discomfort. Repositioning schedule reviewed and increased to 2-hourly. Barrier cream applied. Pressure-relieving cushion in use. Nutrition reviewed - adequate intake. District nurse to assess within 24 hours. Photography and body mapping completed. Waterlow score recalculated - remains high risk. Tissue viability nurse referral made.

Service user became resistive during personal care in Dining Room, pushing staff away and shouting. Care abandoned immediately. Service user left to calm with regular checks from doorway. After 20 minutes, approached by familiar staff member with cup of tea. Service user accepted drink and appeared calmer. Personal care reattempted with different approach - service user cooperative. Trigger appeared to be rushing and feeling pressured. ABC chart completed. Reminder to all staff to allow extra time and not to rush. Service user's preferred routine discussed at handover.

Service user became resistive during personal care in Corridor, pushing staff away and shouting. Care abandoned immediately. Service user left to calm with regular checks from doorway. After 20 minutes, approached by familiar staff member with cup of tea. Service user accepted drink and appeared calmer. Personal care reattempted with different approach - service user cooperative. Trigger appeared to be rushing and feeling pressured. ABC chart completed. Reminder to all staff to allow extra time and not to rush. Service user's preferred routine discussed at handover.

During personal care in Corridor, care staff noticed 3cm skin tear to right forearm. Service user stated they must have caught it on wheelchair but couldn't remember when. Wound cleaned with saline, sterile dressing applied as per tissue viability protocol. Wound photographed and body map completed. Not infected, edges well approximated. District nurse informed - will review at next visit. Skin tear risk assessment updated. Long sleeves recommended to protect fragile skin.

Service user became resistive during personal care in Entrance Hall, pushing staff away and shouting. Care abandoned immediately. Service user left to calm with regular checks from doorway. After 20 minutes, approached by familiar staff member with cup of tea. Service user accepted drink and appeared calmer. Personal care reattempted with different approach - service user cooperative. Trigger appeared to be rushing and feeling pressured. ABC chart completed. Reminder to all staff to allow extra time and not to rush. Service user's preferred routine discussed at handover.

Service user reported to staff in Outside Patio that another service user 'took money from their room'. Senior staff informed immediately. Both service users spoken to separately. Room checked with service user - all belongings accounted for, no money missing. Service user appeared confused about allegation and later could not recall making it. Possible confabulation due to dementia. Documented as potential safeguarding concern. Manager informed, monitoring in place. Family updated. Valuables list checked - all items present.

Service user became resistive during personal care in Outside Patio, pushing staff away and shouting. Care abandoned immediately. Service user left to calm with regular checks from doorway. After 20 minutes, approached by familiar staff member with cup of tea. Service user accepted drink and appeared calmer. Personal care reattempted with different approach - service user cooperative. Trigger appeared to be rushing and feeling pressured. ABC chart completed. Reminder to all staff to allow extra time and not to rush. Service user's preferred routine discussed at handover.

Service user noted missing from Day Room during routine check. Search of building commenced immediately. Not found on premises. CCTV checked - showed service user leaving via main entrance 15 minutes earlier. Police contacted immediately and description provided. Family informed. Staff member searched local area in vehicle. Police located service user 2 streets away, unharmed but confused. Returned to service safely. Full assessment completed - no injuries, appeared well. Mental capacity assessment to be completed. Door security system reviewed. Safeguarding alert raised. Best interest meeting arranged.

Broken window pane discovered in Kitchen during morning checks. Small crack in outer pane, no glass fragments in room. Cause unknown - possibly weather related. Area made safe, room secured and not in use pending repair. Maintenance informed. Emergency glazier contacted - repair scheduled for today. No injuries, no service users in room at time of discovery. All windows to be inspected as precaution. Manager notified.

During medication round in Garden, staff member realised they had administered morning medications to incorrect service user. Error identified immediately. Both service users' medications checked - no harmful medications swapped. Senior staff informed immediately, both service users monitored closely for next 4 hours. No adverse effects noted. GP contacted and advised continued monitoring. Families informed and apologised to. Staff member retrained on checking procedures. Incident reviewed at clinical governance meeting.

Service user refused all morning medications in Corridor stating 'I don't need them'. Staff attempted gentle persuasion explaining importance of medication but service user became agitated. Decision made not to force medication to maintain relationship. Senior staff informed. Further attempt made 1 hour later by different staff member - medications accepted without issue. Mental capacity regarding medication decisions to be reviewed. GP aware.

brief_description: Verbal aggression towards staff during personal care
body_text: During morning personal care in Corridor, service user became verbally aggressive, shouting and swearing at care staff. Staff member stepped back, gave space, and spoke calmly. Service user continued to refuse care. Staff left room for 10 minutes then returned with different colleague. Service user had calmed and accepted care from new staff member. Possible triggers: overtired, preferred male carer not available. ABC chart completed. Behaviour support plan reviewed - no changes needed. Service user later apologised to staff.

Service user began choking while eating lunch in Dining Room. Staff member immediately intervened, encouraged coughing. Obstruction cleared after 3-4 strong coughs. Service user recovered quickly, breathing normally. Remained seated and observed for 15 minutes. No respiratory distress noted. Meal discontinued as precaution. SALT referral made urgently. Swallowing assessment to be completed before resuming normal diet. Soft diet and supervision implemented meanwhile. GP informed. Family contacted.

During personal care in Kitchen, staff member noticed several bruises to upper arms (approximately 2-3cm each, yellow/green in colour). Service user unable to explain how bruises occurred. Body map completed and photographed. Senior staff informed immediately. Safeguarding alert raised as per policy. Recent visitors and activities reviewed. No concerns identified but monitoring continues. Family contacted - unaware of any incidents. Safeguarding team to investigate. Service user observed for any further marks or changes in behaviour.

Observations normal. Encouraged to rest. Physiotherapy referral made for mobility review.

brief_description: Service user found on floor in Outside Patio
body_text: Staff member entered Outside Patio at 16:31 and found service user sitting on the floor. Service user stated they had been reaching for their walking frame and lost balance. No visible injuries noted. Vital signs checked and within normal limits. Neurological observations commenced as per falls protocol. Service user assisted to chair with hoist. Comfortable and alert. Family notified. Incident form completed. GP informed - no further action required at this time.

Service user began choking while eating lunch in Bedroom. Staff member immediately intervened, encouraged coughing. Obstruction cleared after 3-4 strong coughs. Service user recovered quickly, breathing normally. Remained seated and observed for 15 minutes. No respiratory distress noted. Meal discontinued as precaution. SALT referral made urgently. brief_description: Physical aggression - grabbed staff member's arm
body_text: While providing assistance in Corridor, service user suddenly grabbed staff member's left forearm tightly. Staff member remained calm, asked service user to let go, which they did after approximately 5 seconds. Small red mark visible on staff arm but no broken skin. Cold compress applied, mark faded within 30 minutes. Service user appeared confused and did not recognise what had happened. Possible pain trigger - appeared to grimace when moved. PRN analgesia offered and accepted. Behaviour settled. No injury to staff member. Staff member completed incident form and body map.

brief_description: Service user found on floor in Conservatory
body_text: Staff member entered Conservatory at 09:07 and found service user sitting on the floor. Service user stated they had been reaching for their walking frame and lost balance. No visible injuries noted. Vital signs checked and within normal limits. Neurological observations commenced as per falls protocol. Service user assisted to chair with hoist. Comfortable and alert. Family notified. Incident form completed. GP informed - no further action required at this time.

brief_description: Physical aggression - grabbed staff member's arm
body_text: While providing assistance in Bathroom, service user suddenly grabbed staff member's left forearm tightly. Staff member remained calm, asked service user to let go, which they did after approximately 5 seconds. Small red mark visible on staff arm but no broken skin. Cold compress applied, mark faded within 30 minutes. Service user appeared confused and did not recognise what had happened. Possible pain trigger - appeared to grimace when moved. PRN analgesia offered and accepted. Behaviour settled. No injury to staff member. Staff member completed incident form and body map.

Service user began choking while eating lunch in Wet Room. Staff member immediately intervened, encouraged coughing. Obstruction cleared after 3-4 strong coughs. Service user recovered quickly, breathing normally. Remained seated and observed for 15 minutes. No respiratory distress noted. Meal discontinued as precaution. SALT referral made urgently. Swallowing assessment to be completed before resuming normal diet. Soft diet and supervision implemented meanwhile. GP informed. Family contacted.

Service user refused all morning medications in Corridor stating 'I don't need them'. Staff attempted gentle persuasion explaining importance of medication but service user became agitated. Decision made not to force medication to maintain relationship. Senior staff informed. Further attempt made 1 hour later by different staff member - medications accepted without issue. Mental capacity regarding medication decisions to be reviewed. GP aware.

Broken window pane discovered in Outside Patio during morning checks. Small crack in outer pane, no glass fragments in room. Cause unknown - possibly weather related. Area made safe, room secured and not in use pending repair. Maintenance informed. Emergency glazier contacted - repair scheduled for today. No injuries, no service users in room at time of discovery. All windows to be inspected as precaution. Manager notified.

Routine monthly weighing in Corridor showed service user has lost 4kg in past month (current weight 52kg). Senior staff informed. Food charts reviewed - intake appears adequate but fluctuating. GP referral made urgently. Dietitian input requested. Possible causes being investigated - dental problems, infection, medication side effects, low mood. Daily food and fluid monitoring implemented. Fortified diet commenced. Family informed and concerned - will visit to encourage eating. MUST score calculated - medium risk.

Trigger appeared to be rushing and feeling pressured. ABC chart completed. Reminder to all staff to allow extra time and not to rush. Service user's preferred routine discussed at handover.

During medication round in Dining Room, staff member realised they had administered morning medications to incorrect service user. Error identified immediately. During personal care in Kitchen, staff member noticed several bruises to upper arms (approximately 2-3cm each, yellow/green in colour). Service user unable to explain how bruises occurred. brief_description: Verbal aggression towards staff during personal care
body_text: During morning personal care in Kitchen, service user became verbally aggressive, shouting and swearing at care staff. Staff member stepped back, gave space, and spoke calmly. Service user continued to refuse care. Staff left room for 10 minutes then returned with different colleague. Service user had calmed and accepted care from new staff member. Possible triggers: overtired, preferred male carer not available. ABC chart completed. Behaviour support plan reviewed - no changes needed. Service user later apologised to staff.

Service user experienced tonic-clonic seizure in Conservatory lasting approximately 2 minutes. Staff protected head with cushion, cleared area, timed seizure, placed in recovery position once jerking stopped. Post-ictal period - confused and drowsy for approximately 20 minutes. Vital signs monitored and stable. Known epilepsy, last seizure 6 months ago. No injuries sustained during seizure. Recovery uneventful. GP contacted - medication review arranged. Detailed seizure record completed. Neurological observations continued for 4 hours post-seizure.

Service user reported to staff in Corridor that another service user 'took money from their room'. Senior staff informed immediately. Both service users spoken to separately. Room checked with service user - all belongings accounted for, no money missing. Service user appeared confused about allegation and later could not recall making it. Possible confabulation due to dementia. Documented as potential safeguarding concern. Manager informed, monitoring in place. Family updated. Valuables list checked - all items present.

Service user began choking while eating lunch in Activity Room. Staff member immediately intervened, encouraged coughing. Obstruction cleared after 3-4 strong coughs. Service user recovered quickly, breathing normally. Remained seated and observed for 15 minutes. No respiratory distress noted. Meal discontinued as precaution. SALT referral made urgently. Swallowing assessment to be completed before resuming normal diet. Soft diet and supervision implemented meanwhile. GP informed. Family contacted.

Tablet (later identified as Amlodipine 5mg) found on floor in Dining Room during cleaning. Unable to determine which service user this belonged to. All service users in area checked - all MAR charts showed medications signed as given. Tablet disposed of as per policy. All staff reminded to observe service users swallowing medications. Medication administration procedures reviewed with team.

District nurse informed - will review at next visit. Skin tear risk assessment updated. Long sleeves recommended to protect fragile skin.

Door security system reviewed. Safeguarding alert raised. Best interest meeting arranged.

During assisted transfer from wheelchair to armchair in Activity Room, service user's legs gave way. Staff member supported controlled descent to floor, preventing injury. Service user assessed on floor - no pain or obvious injury. Assistance requested, two staff used hoist to transfer to bed for full assessment. Appeared shaken but no injuries sustained. Observations normal. Encouraged to rest. Physiotherapy referral made for mobility review.

Vital signs monitored and stable. Known epilepsy, last seizure 6 months ago. No injuries sustained during seizure. Recovery uneventful. GP contacted - medication review arranged. Detailed seizure record completed. Neurological observations continued for 4 hours post-seizure.

Tablet (later identified as Amlodipine 5mg) found on floor in Garden during cleaning. Unable to determine which service user this belonged to. All service users in area checked - all MAR charts showed medications signed as given. Tablet disposed of as per policy. All staff reminded to observe service users swallowing medications. Medication administration procedures reviewed with team.

Service user noted missing from Corridor during routine check. Search of building commenced immediately. Not found on premises. CCTV checked - showed service user leaving via main entrance 15 minutes earlier. Police contacted immediately and description provided. Family informed. Staff member searched local area in vehicle. Police located service user 2 streets away, unharmed but confused. Returned to service safely. Full assessment completed - no injuries, appeared well. Mental capacity assessment to be completed. Door security system reviewed. Safeguarding alert raised. Best interest meeting arranged.

During personal care in Conservatory, staff member noticed several bruises to upper arms (approximately 2-3cm each, yellow/green in colour). Service user unable to explain how bruises occurred. Body map completed and photographed. Senior staff informed immediately. Safeguarding alert raised as per policy. Recent visitors and activities reviewed. No concerns identified but monitoring continues. Family contacted - unaware of any incidents. Safeguarding team to investigate. Service user observed for any further marks or changes in behaviour.

Broken window pane discovered in Dining Room during morning checks. Small crack in outer pane, no glass fragments in room. Cause unknown - possibly weather related. Area made safe, room secured and not in use pending repair. Maintenance informed. Emergency glazier contacted - repair scheduled for today. No injuries, no service users in room at time of discovery. All windows to be inspected as precaution. Manager notified.

Water leak discovered in ceiling of Garden during routine checks. Area immediately cordoned off, service users moved to alternative location. Maintenance contacted - attended within 30 minutes. Leak from bathroom above identified and isolated. Ceiling assessed - no immediate collapse risk but requires repair. Room out of use until repairs completed. Manager informed, contractors arranged for tomorrow. No service users or staff affected. All equipment removed from room.

During personal care in Dining Room, care staff noticed 3cm skin tear to right forearm. Service user stated they must have caught it on wheelchair but couldn't remember when. Wound cleaned with saline, sterile dressing applied as per tissue viability protocol. Wound photographed and body map completed. Not infected, edges well approximated. District nurse informed - will review at next visit. Skin tear risk assessment updated. Long sleeves recommended to protect fragile skin.

Observations normal. Encouraged to rest. Physiotherapy referral made for mobility review.

Routine monthly weighing in Bathroom showed service user has lost 4kg in past month (current weight 52kg). Senior staff informed. Food charts reviewed - intake appears adequate but fluctuating. GP referral made urgently. Dietitian input requested. Possible causes being investigated - dental problems, infection, medication side effects, low mood. Daily food and fluid monitoring implemented. Fortified diet commenced. Family informed and concerned - will visit to encourage eating. MUST score calculated - medium risk.

brief_description: Verbal aggression towards staff during personal care
body_text: During morning personal care in Kitchen, service user became verbally aggressive, shouting and swearing at care staff. Staff member stepped back, gave space, and spoke calmly. Service user continued to refuse care. Staff left room for 10 minutes then returned with different colleague. Service user had calmed and accepted care from new staff member. Possible triggers: overtired, preferred male carer not available. ABC chart completed. Behaviour support plan reviewed - no changes needed. Service user later apologised to staff.

brief_description: Service user found on floor in Outside Patio
body_text: Staff member entered Outside Patio at 14:05 and found service user sitting on the floor. Service user stated they had been reaching for their walking frame and lost balance. No visible injuries noted. Vital signs checked and within normal limits. Neurological observations commenced as per falls protocol. Service user assisted to chair with hoist. Comfortable and alert. Family notified. Incident form completed. GP informed - no further action required at this time.

brief_description: Exit-seeking behaviour - attempted to leave building
body_text: Service user found at front entrance in Activity Room attempting to open the door stating they needed to 'get home to cook dinner'. Gently redirected by staff using distraction technique. Offered cup of tea and biscuit which was accepted. Walked with staff to lounge where familiar music was playing. Became settled and engaged in conversation about past. Appeared to forget about leaving. Family member telephoned to provide reassurance which helped. No distress caused. Security settings on door checked and functioning correctly.

Routine monthly weighing in Wet Room showed service user has lost 4kg in past month (current weight 52kg). Senior staff informed. Food charts reviewed - intake appears adequate but fluctuating. GP referral made urgently. Dietitian input requested. Possible causes being investigated - dental problems, infection, medication side effects, low mood. Daily food and fluid monitoring implemented. Fortified diet commenced. Family informed and concerned - will visit to encourage eating. MUST score calculated - medium risk.

Service user began choking while eating lunch in Corridor. Staff member immediately intervened, encouraged coughing. Obstruction cleared after 3-4 strong coughs. Service user recovered quickly, breathing normally. Remained seated and observed for 15 minutes. No respiratory distress noted. Meal discontinued as precaution. SALT referral made urgently. Swallowing assessment to be completed before resuming normal diet. Soft diet and supervision implemented meanwhile. GP informed. Family contacted.

brief_description: Physical aggression - grabbed staff member's arm
body_text: While providing assistance in Bathroom, service user suddenly grabbed staff member's left forearm tightly. Staff member remained calm, asked service user to let go, which they did after approximately 5 seconds. Small red mark visible on staff arm but no broken skin. Cold compress applied, mark faded within 30 minutes. Service user appeared confused and did not recognise what had happened. Possible pain trigger - appeared to grimace when moved. PRN analgesia offered and accepted. Behaviour settled. No injury to staff member. Staff member completed incident form and body map.
